Award.AwardTitle: Addressing the Scientific, Technological and Societal Challenges of the Energy, Water, and Food Nexus: Enabling Resiliency in Energy, Water, and Food Systems for Society
Award.AbstractNarration:
Transformative changes in our production of secure and sustainable energy, food, and water sources, and in the efficient use of energy, are among the most significant challenges of the 21st Century, initially manifesting in regions like Arizona and the Southwestern U.S. and eventually the entire country. Professors Neal Armstrong, Kimberly Ogden, and Ardeth Barnhart, MPA of the University of Arizona are organizing a workshop that seeks to address those challenges in a focused manner, producing outcomes that will inform: i) the academic participants who will be called upon to create the research efforts required to address these challenges; ii) the agencies who will be required to create optimized funding opportunities which ensure broad based participation, and significant outcomes; and iii) the decision makers and general public who will be the consumers of these scientific, technology development, and policy and economic analysis research efforts.

The workshop, supported by the Division of Chemistry, is entitled, "Addressing the Scientific, Technological and Societal Challenges of the Energy, Water, and Food Nexus: Enabling Resiliency in Energy, Water, and Food Systems for Society," is to be held April 16-17, 2015 at Biosphere 2 near Tucson, Arizona. This workshop will bring together a select group of representatives from academic institutions, government and industry to help identify the top scientific questions that address the pressing global need to secure the availability of energy, water and food for future generations. Underlying the discussions will be the recognition from the outset that proposed solutions cannot a priori require more energy (and water) than they deliver, which has been a common occurrence in technological developments in the recent past. Formal presentations and breakout discussions will occur in parallel sessions organized around five general topics: 1) New energy sources for water and food, 2) Energy efficient water re-use and purification, 3) Energy, water and food systems, 4) Economics, policy, business and society, and 5) Technology and infrastructure. The outcomes of these sessions will be integrated during a final plenary session. The results of the workshop will be disseminated through a workshop report.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: On April 15-17, 2015, the University of Arizona (UA) convened a workshop at Biosphere 2 focused on: “Addressing the Scientific, Technological and Societal Challenges of the Energy, Water, and Food Nexus (EWF): Enabling Resiliency in Energy, Water, and Food Systems for Society,” seeking an interdisciplinary approach to addressing the scientific challenges in energy, water, and food systems that impact the U.S.

With support from the National Science Foundation (NSF), the UA Renewable Energy Network (UAREN), and the UA Office of Research and Discovery (ORD), we convened representatives from academia, government, and industry to identify the top scientific questions that underpin the availability of energy, clean water, and secure food supplies.

Intellectual Merit:

The workshop on the Energy, Water, and Food Nexus resulted in five specific themes stimulating basic research and providing key foundational knowledge:

i. Situational scarcity: Energy, water, food, and the materials that underpin our economic viability (e.g. strategic minerals and fuels), can be extremely scarce in localized regions and at different periods of time, affecting the well-being of large portions of the U.S.  Research initiatives are needed that address the challenges of situational scarcity, at the molecule-, material-, and system-scale, accompanied by an evaluation of their anticipated economic and societal impacts.

ii. New materials, new technologies, and unit operations are needed which are flexibly targeted to:

• Energy-efficient water reuse and purification;

• Distributed energy sources and energy storage platforms;

• Widely dispersed, multi-analyte sensor platforms.

Development of these new technologies will be led by an atomic- and molecular-scale understanding of separations, molecular recognition, and charge transfer and catalysis.

iii. Smart data and decision-making: Integrated modes of dealing with situational scarcity will be linked to measurement, analysis, and optimization (control) of chemical and physical parameters on previously unrealized (large) scales. Massive data sets will be generated requiring new modes of transmission, storage, access, and robust links to policy and decision-making processes.

iv. Policy Response: Policy focus on the following areas is essential: a) bottom-up integration of both new science and new technology with policy development, decision-making and support, and education and awareness; b) revitalization of local communities coupled with human resource, and workforce development; c) development of policies that transform the regulatory and market environment; d) integrated and coordinated planning across sectors and public and private organizations.

v. Regional Test Beds and Private/Pubic Partnerships: Regionally specific test beds are needed that must be: a) large and complex enough to challenge the integration of new energy conversion, energy storage, and energy management systems, coupled with new water purification platforms, and new precision agricultural systems; and b) small enough to be easily isolated so that credible and verifiable research results are achievable. The University of Arizona Biosphere 2 facility (http://b2science.org/) has the potential to become one of these sites.

Broader Impacts:

This workshop produced several specific recommendations accessible on the conference web site: http://energywaterfoodnexus.wordpress.com
